question.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect?

options.text: In Australian acacia, the petioles expand, become green and synthesize food.
If more than two leaves arise at a node and form a whorl, it is called whorled, as in mustard.
In palmately compound leaves, the leaflets are attached at a common point, i.e., at the tip of the petiole, as in silk cotton.
Leaves of dicotyledonous plants generally possess reticulate venation, while parallel venation is the characteristic of most monocotyledons.

solution.text: In the alternate type of phyllotaxy, a single leaf arises at each node in an alternate manner, as in china rose, mustard and sunflower plants. If more than two leaves arise at a node and form a whorl, it is called whorled, as in Alstonia.
